issue.title: Unlimited recursion on Windows with Python 2.7

repository.name: python-atomicwrites
repository.description: Powerful Python library for atomic file writes.

issue.body:
I bumped to the latest pytest which now needs atomicwrites... and the tests fail to run on Windows.
I am under the impression that atomicwrites is the culprit but I may be wrong?

See https://ci.appveyor.com/project/nexB/license-expression/build/248/job/smx1qy33w1dxrlh5#L531
and https://ci.appveyor.com/project/nexB/license-expression/build/248/job/jpd8c35tgee9mi7y#L532

Things work fine on POSIX and other Python versions on Windows:
https://travis-ci.org/nexB/license-expression/builds/383421178
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/nexB/license-expression/build/248
 
The exact versions used are here:
https://github.com/nexB/license-expression/tree/fix-symbol-comparison/thirdparty/dev

body: [GitMate.io](https://gitmate.io) thinks possibly related issues are https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/2501 (maximum recursion depth exceeded), https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/2327 (capsys not capturing on Python 2.7), https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/3 (not executable on Python 2.7), https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/323 (Parametrization leads to RuntimeError: maximum recursion depth exceeded), and https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/2642 (Introduce six to the codebase to deal with Python 2/Python 3 differences).

Hi @pombredanne,

Here's the interesting part of the traceback:

```
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\_pytest\assertion\rewrite.py", line 271, in _write_pyc
    marshal.dump(co, fp)
  File "C:\Python27\Lib\contextlib.py", line 24, in __exit__
    self.gen.next()
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\atomicwrites\__init__.py", line 152, in _open
    self.commit(f)
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\atomicwrites\__init__.py", line 177, in commit
    replace_atomic(f.name, self._path)
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\atomicwrites\__init__.py", line 89, in replace_atomic
    return _replace_atomic(src, dst)
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\atomicwrites\__init__.py", line 70, in _replace_atomic
    _path_to_unicode(src), _path_to_unicode(dst),
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\atomicwrites\__init__.py", line 21, in _path_to_unicode
    return x.decode(sys.getfilesystemencoding())
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\encodings\__init__.py", line 100, in search_function
    level=0)
  File "c:\projects\license-expression\lib\site-packages\_pytest\assertion\rewrite.py", line 145, in find_module
    _write_pyc(state, co, source_stat, pyc)
```

`c:\projects\license-expression\lib\encodings\__init__.py", line 100` is:

```python
        try:
            # Import is absolute to prevent the possibly malicious import of a
            # module with side-effects that is not in the 'encodings' package.
            mod = __import__('encodings.' + modname, fromlist=_import_tail,
                             level=0)
        except ImportError:
```

So when `atomicwrites` tries to write the file, this triggers an import, which triggers the rewriter again, and so on.

I will have to think how to solve this...

Hmmm possibly a fix is to call `sys.getfilesystemencoding()` before the `atomicwrite` call.

Any chance of providing a reproducible example @pombredanne? Alternatively, I can push an experiment to my fork and you can install pytest from there to see if it works?

@nicoddemus I can reproduce things at this commit exactly https://github.com/nexB/license-expression/commit/e4040b356abd07dc730477b75ffd8646be669b3a
The difficulty would be to find a trimmed down example .... though the license-expression library is rather simple: just two python files and one dep and only two test files.
No problem, would it be easy for you to install pytest from my fork at a specific branch?
@nicoddemus sure, I can tweak a branch alright to get any custom py.test installed.

FWIW, this issue affects all three of the Pyramid cookiecutters.
* https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Pylons/pyramid-cookiecutter-starter/build/master.104/job/gk9crhyvd4rt7gt9?fullLog=true#L1397
* https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Pylons/pyramid-cookiecutter-alchemy/build/job/xuubi9ket7sgfltm#L1392
* https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Pylons/pyramid-cookiecutter-zodb/build/job/adnynv6xm7tom0qs#L1452

issue.title: Use minimum version of pytest with bug fix for pytest-dev/pytest#3506

repository.name: pyramid-cookiecutter-starter
repository.description: A Cookiecutter (project template) for creating a Pyramid starter project with choices for template language (Jinja2, Chameleon, or Mako), persistent backend (none, SQLAlchemy with SQLite, or ZODB), and mapping of URLs to routes (URL dispatch or traversal)

issue.body: We have to run tests on Windows for Python 2.7, but the current version of pytest has a bug that causes an infinite recursion. There is an open issue at https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/3506. When pytest fixes that issue, then we can change the minimum version of pytest to that. The issue is open as of pytest 3.7.3, released 2018-08-26.

issue.title: Use minimum version of pytest with bug fix for pytest-dev/pytest#3506

issue.title: Testing pytest recursion error fix - DO NOT MERGE

issue.body:
This commit is testing to ensure the fix for issue pytest-dev/pytest#3506
actually works.

body:
Thanks @stevepiercy, this issue got off my radar.

I've opened https://github.com/Pylons/pyramid-cookiecutter-starter/pull/56 to test a candidate fix. This works locally, but I want to make sure.

No idea how I will test for this though...
